latest news.eng_title: Naji Sawiris Calls for Unity and Peace in the Region
latest news.summary: Egyptian actor Naji Sawiris expressed his support for unity and peace in the region, calling for an end to the escalation of tensions between Egypt, Somalia, and Ethiopia. He shared a tweet from an Ethiopian account, writing 'You are right', which stated 'Egypt, Somalia, and Ethiopia are like one state. We should not allow those who drum the beat of war to succeed in their attempts to destabilize us. Destabilizing the Horn of Africa will lead to the destruction of Africa.' The account added 'Africa yearns for unity, not war.' Relations between Somalia and Ethiopia have been tense in recent months, following the signing of a disputed agreement between Addis Ababa and the breakaway region of Somaliland. The agreement aims to secure a piece of land in the Gulf of Aden for Ethiopia, in exchange for recognizing Somaliland as an independent republic. Ethiopia has already sent a diplomat to Hargeisa, marking a significant step in diplomatic recognition. In response, Somali President Hassan Sheikh Mohamud visited Cairo, seeking Egyptian support, and a defense agreement was signed between the two countries in August, with Egypt sending military equipment and troops to Mogadishu. It is expected that Egypt will participate in a new UN peacekeeping mission in Somalia next year.
latest news.title: نجيب ساويرس يعلق على أزمة مصر والصومال وإثيوبيا.. ماذا قال؟

latest news.eng_title: Egypt's Strategic Move in Somalia: Countering Ethiopia's Influence
latest news.summary: Egypt has sent a large number of troops to Somalia, with around 10,000 soldiers, as part of its participation in the African Union's peacekeeping mission. This move has been seen as a strategic step by Egypt to counter Ethiopia's influence in the region, particularly in the context of the Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam (GERD) crisis. Egypt has been concerned about Ethiopia's plans to fill the dam, which could affect its share of the Nile's water. The Egyptian government has been trying to negotiate with Ethiopia, but so far, no agreement has been reached. The presence of Egyptian troops in Somalia is also seen as a way for Egypt to project its power and influence in the region, and to counter Ethiopia's attempts to establish a military base in the Red Sea. Additionally, Egypt has been working to strengthen its relations with other countries in the region, including Turkey, which has also been involved in the GERD crisis. Egypt and Turkey have signed a defense and economic cooperation agreement, and have been working together to support Somalia's government and military. The Egyptian government has also been trying to promote its own model of counter-terrorism cooperation with Somalia, which has been a key player in the fight against al-Qaeda and other terrorist groups in the region. The presence of Egyptian troops in Somalia is seen as a way for Egypt to demonstrate its commitment to regional security and stability, and to promote its own interests in the region.
latest news.title: مصر في الصومال: خطوة محسوبة وأغراض متعدّدة

latest news.source_id: Institute for the Study of War
latest news.eng_title: Africa File, September 5, 2024: Egypt, Ethiopia, and Somalia Conflict Looms; IS Gains in Niger; Russia Aids Burkina Faso's Nuclear Energy Push
latest news.summary: The Africa File reports on several conflicts in Africa, including the growing tensions between Egypt, Ethiopia, and Somalia. Egypt has deployed troops to Somalia, increasing regional tensions, while Ethiopia has warned that the growing Egyptian military presence on its border poses a national security threat. The African Union peacekeeping transition at the end of 2024 is a potential trigger that could transform the rising political tensions into an armed conflict between Egyptian and Somali forces against Ethiopian soldiers. In Niger, the Islamic State Sahel Province (ISSP) has cut off a district capital, threatening to expand its control in the Burkina Faso, Mali, and Niger border area. Meanwhile, Burkina Faso is advancing its nuclear energy goals with Russian support. The report also notes that the growing tensions between Egypt and Ethiopia could undermine upcoming Turkish-led peace talks between the two countries. Additionally, Turkey's recent rapprochement with Egypt may impact its mediator role in the conflict.
latest news.title: Africa File, September 5, 2024: Egypt, Ethiopia, and Somalia Conflict Looms; IS Gains in Niger; Russia Aids Burkina Faso's Nuclear Energy Push

latest news.eng_title: Egypt and Ethiopia on Brink of War in Somalia
latest news.summary: Egypt and Ethiopia are preparing for a potential armed conflict in Somalia. According to the Guardian, Egypt has begun deploying a 5,000-strong military contingent to Somalia, which will be reinforced with tanks and aircraft. The move is allegedly aimed at helping Somalia after the planned withdrawal of the African Union peacekeeping force at the end of the year. However, observers believe that Egyptian troops may be redeployed to the border between Somalia and Ethiopia. The situation is complicated by the presence of Ethiopian forces in Somalia, which are fighting against terrorist groups. Ethiopia claims that it 'cannot remain idle while other subjects destabilize the region', accuses Somalia of conspiring with Egypt, and is preparing to 'take measures to respond'. Experts believe that the tensions between Egypt and Ethiopia in Somalia, as well as the issues of Somaliland's existence and access to maritime ports, are a continuation of the longstanding rivalry between Addis Ababa and Cairo over the Renaissance Dam on the Blue Nile. Egypt views the dam as a threat to its existence, as the river provides 85% of the country's water consumption. 'Egypt considers Ethiopia's policy to be a threat to regional stability,' says the Egyptian Foreign Ministry. 'Cairo is ready to take all necessary measures to protect its right to exist, as well as the rights and interests of its citizens.' As Egypt is 'prepared to act until the end in the interests of self-defense', and Ethiopia is 'determined to defend its interests', experts predict that a full-scale war in northeastern Africa may erupt in the near future.
latest news.title: Египет и Эфиопия готовятся к вооруженному конфликту - Российская газета

latest news.eng_title: Egypt's involvement in Somalia signals new and precarious chapter in dispute with Ethiopia
latest news.summary: Egypt's involvement in Somalia is a new and precarious chapter in its dispute with Ethiopia. Egyptian President Abdel Fattah El Sisi has sent troops and arms to Somalia, which has been at odds with Ethiopia over the Nile waters. The move is seen as a way to pressure Ethiopia into a more flexible approach towards the dam dispute. 'It would not have been possible for a nation [Egypt] with so much history and rights to Nile waters to remain silent when faced with the absurdity that Ethiopia has shown us in recent years,' said Mustafa Al Fiqy, a retired career Egyptian diplomat. Egypt has also forged closer relations with some of Ethiopia's neighbours and fellow Nile basin nations, lending them its expertise and occasionally sending aid. However, the move has angered Ethiopia, which has warned that the intervention of outside forces in Somalia would destabilise the region. Egypt has countered by complaining in a letter to the UN Security Council about what it called Ethiopia's unilateral policies over the Gerd. The heightened tension between Egypt and Ethiopia would further destabilise the Horn of Africa and the larger East Africa region, which is already shaken by a 16-month civil war in Sudan and attacks on Red Sea shipping by the Iran-backed Houthi rebels in Yemen. 'I don't think that the Egyptian move will necessarily set off a war in the Horn of Africa, but it's indicative of persistent tension there,' said Michael Hanna, a New York-based Middle East expert with the International Crisis Group think tank.
latest news.title: Egypt's involvement in Somalia signals new and precarious chapter in dispute with Ethiopia

latest news.eng_title: East Africa: The Horn - a Lot in Common, Little to Dispute, Shun Third Party
latest news.summary: The recent tension between Ethiopia and Somalia has escalated, with Somalia refusing to accept Ethiopia's call for mutual benefit and access to the sea. Ethiopia has been a major player in regional issues, sacrificing its sons and daughters for the well-being of the region, and has been a frontrunner in fighting terrorism and supporting nations to stand on their feet as sovereign nations. Professor Brook Hailu noted that Ethiopia's contributions to Somalia's peace are often overlooked, including its troops being on the front lines against Al-Shabaab and building essential infrastructure in Somalia. However, Somalia's recent actions, including its closer tie with Egypt, a country with a contentious history with Ethiopia, pose a significant threat to Ethiopia's national interests. Ethiopia feels sidelined and fears these developments could reverse its achievements in the region. The Somali government must reconsider its security strategy and collaborate with neighboring countries like Ethiopia, as excluding them risks losing control over many regions. 'How could the Cairo government manage Somalia's peace? I see no likelihood of this,' questioned the scholar. Ethiopia argues it should not be excluded from post-ATMIS peacekeeping efforts and expects support from the African Union and the United Nations Security Council in this regard.
latest news.title: East Africa: The Horn - a Lot in Common, Little to Dispute, Shun Third Party

latest news.eng_title: Egyptian-Turkish Cooperation in Somalia: A New Era of Mediation
latest news.summary: Egypt has sent 10,000 troops to Somalia, with half of them under the African Union's peacekeeping mission 'AMISOM' and the other half near the Ethiopian border. This move is a significant development in Egypt's foreign policy, as Cairo has historically avoided involvement in conflict zones. However, Egypt has been cooperating with Turkey in the region, particularly in Somalia and Ethiopia. Turkey has been actively involved in the region, with a strong military and economic presence. It has a defense agreement with Somalia and has been providing military training and aid to the Somali army. Turkey's relations with Ethiopia date back to 130 years and include several security and economic agreements. Turkey has been playing a mediating role between Egypt and Ethiopia, helping to resolve their differences. The Egyptian move is seen as a response to Ethiopia's fifth filling of the Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam, which has deepened tensions between the two countries. The Egyptian government has expressed its opposition to Ethiopia's unilateral actions, and the two countries are engaged in negotiations over the dam's impact on Egypt's water rights. Turkey's role in mediating between Egypt and Ethiopia is seen as crucial in resolving the dispute. The two countries agree on the need to maintain the unity and sovereignty of Somalia and reject any attempts at secession. They also agree on the need to address the ongoing Israeli aggression against the Palestinian people in Gaza and the West Bank, the Sudanese crisis, and the situation in Libya. The success of Egyptian-Turkish cooperation in Somalia could serve as a model for cooperation in other sensitive files in the region.
latest news.title: ما بعد التعاون التركي المصري في الصومال

latest news.eng_title: Egypt's Military Deployment in Somalia: A Response to Ethiopia's Ambitions
latest news.summary: Egypt has sent troops to Somalia, a move that has raised concerns about the country's intentions in the region. The deployment is seen as a response to Ethiopia's plans to build a dam on the Nile River, which Egypt fears will affect its water supply. Egypt has long been concerned about Ethiopia's ambitions in the region, and the dam project has been a major point of contention between the two countries. The Egyptian government has stated that it will not allow Ethiopia to control the Nile River's water supply, and has taken steps to strengthen its military presence in the region. Egypt's move to send troops to Somalia is seen as a way to counterbalance Ethiopia's influence in the region and to protect its own interests. The deployment is also seen as a way for Egypt to assert its leadership in the region and to promote its own vision for Africa's future. Egyptian experts say that the country's strategy in the region is to promote peace and stability, and to support the development of African countries. They also say that Egypt's presence in Somalia is not just about military power, but also about economic and cultural exchange. The deployment of Egyptian troops to Somalia is seen as a significant development in the region, and has been welcomed by some as a positive step towards promoting peace and stability in Africa.
latest news.title: Mısır'ın Somali'deki askerleri: Afrika stratejisi yeniden şekilleniyor

latest news.eng_title: Fact check: Ethiopian leader's speech did not include ‘stern warning' to Somalia and Egypt
latest news.summary: A recent Facebook post claims that Ethiopian Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed issued a 'stern warning' to Somalia and Egypt, but this is misleading. The video clip shared in the post is over three years old and shows Abiy speaking about the war in Ethiopia's Tigray region at the time. Abiy never mentioned Egypt or Somalia in the clip, nor in the original footage of his speech. The post has been shared over 100 times and viewed 13,000 times since it was published on August 30, 2024. 'We must continue to learn, read and prepare. However, we should not boast. We will win when we engage in a war, but we will not boast until we engage,' Abiy says in the 11-second clip. The diplomatic row between Ethiopia and Somalia is ongoing, with the two countries involved in a dispute over a port deal, and Ethiopia's involvement in a long-standing dispute with Egypt over the Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam.
latest news.title: Fact check: Ethiopian leader's speech did not include ‘stern warning' to Somalia and Egypt

latest news.eng_title: Erdogan and Sisi Seek to Strengthen Cooperation After Decade of Estrangement
latest news.summary: Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan and his Egyptian counterpart Abdel Fattah el-Sisi have expressed their desire to 'strengthen their cooperation' after a decade of estrangement. Erdogan said, 'We will strengthen our cooperation in all fields.' The two leaders signed 17 cooperation agreements, according to the Turkish presidency, and reiterated their goal to increase trade exchange to $15 billion annually within five years, up from the current $10 billion. Erdogan emphasized, 'We want to upgrade our cooperation with Egypt in the energy sector, particularly natural gas and nuclear energy.' The two leaders discussed the possibility of transferring Turkish military equipment to Egypt, according to the Turkish presidency. In February, Turkish Foreign Minister Hakan Fidan announced that Turkey had agreed to supply Egypt with military equipment similar to that provided to many African countries. 'A new page has been turned' in relations between the two countries, which deteriorated since 2013 after el-Sisi, then defense minister, ousted President Mohamed Morsi, a Muslim Brotherhood ally of Turkey. Erdogan repeated that he 'will not speak at all' to 'someone like him,' referring to el-Sisi. However, relations between the two leaders have improved, with a convergence of their interests in many regional disputes, including the Gaza Strip. Erdogan said, 'Reaching a ceasefire and delivering humanitarian aid to Gaza is our top priority.' After discussing the 'humanitarian tragedy in Gaza' and the need for a ceasefire, el-Sisi called for 'a halt to escalation in the West Bank,' which has been occupied by Israel since 1967 and where Israeli forces have been conducting a large-scale military operation for a week. The two leaders also discussed the situation in Somalia and agreed on the need to 'preserve the unity and integrity of this country's territory.' Ankara and Cairo have signed several agreements in recent months on military cooperation with Somalia, which is experiencing intense tensions with its neighbor Ethiopia.
latest news.title: اردوغان والسيسي يرغبان في "تعزيز تعاونهما" بعد عقد من القطيعة

news knowledge.eng_title: Djibouti Offers Ethiopia Access to Port of Tadjura
news knowledge.summary: The Republic of Djibouti has announced its willingness to provide Ethiopia with access to the port of Tadjura. According to Djibouti's Foreign Minister, Mahamoud Ali Youssouf, 'Access will be provided to the port of Tadjura, 100 km from the border with Ethiopia.' This move comes after Ethiopia's Prime Minister, Abiy Ahmed, called on neighboring countries in October 2023 to negotiate equal access to ports in exchange for participation in controlling the 'Renaissance Dam.' However, neither Somalia nor Djibouti nor Eritrea responded positively to the proposal. On January 1, 2024, Ahmed and the head of Somaliland, Muse Bihi Abdi, signed a memorandum of understanding to provide Ethiopia with access to maritime ports. In exchange, Somaliland would receive recognition as a sovereign state. Somaliland is recognized by the international community as part of Somalia, but its authorities declared state sovereignty unilaterally in the spring of 1991. The Somali government has stated its intention to challenge the memorandum between Ethiopia and Somaliland, which it believes violates the country's sovereignty. Somali President Hassan Sheikh Mohamud has vowed to take action against Ethiopia without hesitation. In response, Ethiopia's senior advisor to the Chief of Staff, Alemeshet Degefe, stated that Addis Ababa is mobilizing troops to prevent attempts to destabilize the country. The African Union's Peace and Security Council has called on Ethiopia and Somalia to exercise restraint, de-escalate, and establish a productive dialogue.
news knowledge.title: В Джибути сообщили, что предоставят Эфиопии доступ к порту

news knowledge.eng_title: Turkey-Mediated Somalia-Ethiopia Port Deal Fails to Reach Agreement
news knowledge.summary: Talks between Somalia and Ethiopia over a contentious Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) between Ethiopia and Somaliland ended without an agreement in Turkey. Despite the failure, the talks are being viewed as a diplomatic success, as they helped prevent direct confrontation or war between the two nations. The talks, mediated by Turkey, aimed to ease tensions that have persisted since the MoU was signed on January 1, 2024. Somalia denounced the agreement as infringing on its sovereignty and subsequently severed diplomatic ties with Ethiopia. Turkish mediation helped to prevent further escalation, as Somalia's Foreign Minister, Elin, said, 'It was a great day.' However, the exact details of the agreement remain unclear, and the dispute is far from being resolved.
news knowledge.title: Turkey-Mediated Somalia-Ethiopia Port Deal Fails to Reach Agreement

news knowledge.eng_title: Ethiopia-Somaliland Dispute Raises Concerns About Regional Instability
news knowledge.summary: A dispute between Ethiopia and the self-declared state of Somaliland has raised concerns about a potential regional escalation that could threaten maritime security in the Red Sea region. The dispute centers around Ethiopia's desire to establish a naval base on Somaliland territory. The conflict has a long history, dating back to the British colonization of the region. In 1960, Somaliland gained independence from British colonial rule and merged with the Italian colony of Somalia to form the Somali Republic. However, in 1991, Somaliland declared independence from Somalia, and despite not being recognized by the international community, it has its own government, institutions, and currency. The current dispute began in 2024 when Ethiopia and Somaliland signed a memorandum of understanding that would allow Ethiopia to use one of Somaliland's ports for 50 years in exchange for recognizing Somaliland's independence. The agreement has been met with opposition from Somaliland, which has declared the agreement null and void. The United States and the African Union have called for calm and respect for Somaliland's sovereignty, while Turkey has expressed its commitment to Somaliland's unity and territorial integrity. Egypt has also pledged to support Somaliland and has signed a military cooperation agreement with the country. The agreement has been seen as a move by Egypt to counter Ethiopia's influence in the region and to secure its own interests in the Red Sea. The dispute has raised concerns about the potential for regional instability and the impact on maritime security in the Red Sea.
news knowledge.title: نزاع سياسي واقتصادي بمنطقة القرن الإفريقي

news knowledge.eng_title: Ethiopia and Somalia move closer to resolving Somaliland dispute
news knowledge.summary: Ethiopia and Somalia have made 'notable progress' in resolving a dispute over a deal between Ethiopia and Somaliland, a breakaway region claimed by Somalia. The deal, agreed in January, would have Somaliland lease its coastline to Ethiopia for a marine force base in exchange for potential recognition of Somaliland's independence. Turkish Foreign Minister Hakan Fidan said both sides have shown a willingness to engage on the technical details of the dispute, and that a 'collaborative and constructive solution is within reach.' A third round of talks is scheduled for September 17. Somalia's Foreign Minister Ahmed Moallim Fiqi expressed hope that the momentum will result in a solution, while reaffirming Somalia's commitment to protecting its sovereignty, territorial integrity, and unity.
news knowledge.title: Ethiopia and Somalia move closer to resolving Somaliland dispute

news knowledge.eng_title: Turkey Announces 'Notable Progress' in Ethiopia-Somalia Dispute
news knowledge.summary: Turkey's Minister of Foreign Affairs, Hakan Fidan, announced 'notable progress' in the efforts of Ethiopia and Somalia to resolve a dispute caused by Ethiopia's agreement with the Somaliland region. The dispute is over Ethiopia's agreement to recognize Somaliland's independence in exchange for a 20km strip of land along its coastline. Somalia has denounced the agreement as an attack on its sovereignty and territorial integrity. Fidan stated that the number and scope of issues discussed in the second round of talks increased significantly compared to the first round, and that a solution is within reach. A third round of negotiations is scheduled for September 17. Somalia's Minister of Foreign Affairs, Ahmed Moallim Fiqi, expressed hope that the progress made will lead to a solution, but emphasized that Somalia remains determined to protect its sovereignty, territorial integrity, and unity. Ethiopia's Minister of Foreign Affairs, Taye Atske Selassie, thanked Turkey for its mediation and reiterated Ethiopia's desire for a reliable access to the sea and from the sea. 'We are waiting with impatience for a continued commitment that will help us resolve the current disputes and restore normal relations', he said.
news knowledge.title: Somaliland : la Turquie annonce "des progrès" entre l'Ethiopie et la Somalie

news knowledge.eng_title: Turkey says Ethiopia and Somalia have made 'notable progress' in talks to settle dispute
news knowledge.summary: Turkey's Foreign Minister Hakan Fidan announced 'notable progress' in talks between Ethiopia and Somalia to settle a dispute over a deal between Ethiopia and Somaliland. Fidan stated, 'I am pleased to announce that the number and extent of issues we discussed, has increased significantly, compared to the first round. We were able to focus on the details and technicalities of concrete steps.' A third round of talks is scheduled for September 17. The dispute centers around Ethiopia's deal with Somaliland, which includes leasing a 20-kilometer stretch of land along its coastline to establish a marine force base, in exchange for Ethiopia recognizing Somaliland's independence. Somalia has denounced the deal as infringing upon its sovereignty and territorial integrity.
news knowledge.title: Turkey says Ethiopia and Somalia have made 'notable progress' in talks to settle dispute

news knowledge.eng_title: Turkey says Ethiopia and Somalia have made ‘notable progress' in talks to settle dispute
news knowledge.summary: Turkey's foreign minister, Hakan Fidan, announced that Ethiopia and Somalia have made 'notable progress' in talks to settle a dispute sparked by Ethiopia's deal with Somaliland. Fidan stated that the number and extent of issues discussed increased significantly in the second round of talks, and that a collaborative and constructive solution is within reach. A third round of talks is scheduled for September 17. The dispute centers around Ethiopia's deal with Somaliland, which would lease a 20-kilometer stretch of land to Ethiopia to establish a marine force base, in exchange for Ethiopia recognizing Somaliland's independence. Somalia has denounced the deal as infringing upon its sovereignty and territorial integrity, and has said it's prepared to go to war over it. Fidan proposed an arrangement that would ensure Ethiopia's sea access via Somalia, in return for Ethiopia acknowledging Somalia's territorial integrity and political sovereignty. The foreign ministers of Ethiopia and Somalia expressed hope that the momentum from the talks will result in a solution, with Somalia reaffirming its commitment to protecting its sovereignty, territorial integrity, and unity.
news knowledge.title: Turkey says Ethiopia and Somalia have made ‘notable progress' in talks to settle dispute

news knowledge.eng_title: Ethiopia Considers Reconsidering Agreement with Somaliland Amid Somalia's Port Offer
news knowledge.summary: Ethiopia may reconsider its agreement with Somaliland, a secessionist region, after Somalia, backed by Turkey, made an 'attractive' offer to provide access to a port for its trade. Ethiopia, a landlocked country, seeks to access regional ports to strengthen its trade with the rest of the world. The potential agreement between Somalia and Ethiopia would involve Somalia providing Ethiopia with access to a port, and Ethiopia abandoning its protocol with Somaliland, signed on January 1, 2024. This arrangement aims to resolve long-standing tensions between the two countries and improve their diplomatic relations. According to diplomatic reports, the foreign ministers of Ethiopia and Somalia have provisionally accepted a reconciliation proposal presented by Turkey. Somali President Hassan Sheikh Mohamud stated, 'The role of Turkey in promoting dialogue and peaceful resolution of regional problems is essential.' He reiterated Somalia's willingness to engage in economic cooperation and development with Ethiopia, but emphasized that such partnerships must respect Somalia's sovereignty, unity, and territorial integrity, and adhere to international law and norms. Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan previously tweeted that he had spoken with Ethiopian Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed, saying, 'If Ethiopia takes measures to end any threat to Somalia's sovereignty and territorial integrity, it will facilitate the discussion process.' This statement implies that Ethiopia must officially renounce its agreement with Somaliland to move forward with the proposed arrangement. It is not yet clear if Addis-Abeba has renounced the agreement with Somaliland.
news knowledge.title: Accès portuaire : l'Ethiopie va-t-elle dénoncer l'accord avec le Somaliland ?

news knowledge.eng_title: Turkey Hosts Second Round of Talks Between Somalia and Ethiopia
news knowledge.summary: Turkey is hosting a second round of talks between Somalia and Ethiopia, as part of its mediation efforts to resolve a dispute over a port agreement signed by Ethiopia with the breakaway region of Somaliland in January 2023, which allows Somaliland to use the region's coastline on the Red Sea for commercial and military purposes for 50 years. According to a statement by the Turkish presidency, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan spoke with Ethiopian Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed by phone, discussing the relations between Turkey and Ethiopia, regional and global developments, and the dispute with Somalia. Erdogan emphasized that Turkey will continue its efforts to end the tension between Somalia and Ethiopia, and that Ethiopia's steps to address Somalia's concerns about its unity, sovereignty, and territorial integrity 'will make the process easier.' The Turkish Foreign Minister, Hakan Fidan, said that the foreign ministers of Somalia and Ethiopia will meet in Ankara this week to discuss the dispute over the port agreement. The relations between the two neighbors, Ethiopia and Somalia, have deteriorated since Ethiopia signed the agreement with Somaliland in January 2023, which allows Somaliland to use the region's coastline on the Red Sea for commercial and military purposes for 50 years, in exchange for Ethiopia's recognition of Somaliland's independence. In April 2023, Somalia announced the expulsion of the Ethiopian ambassador, and closed the Ethiopian consulates in Hargeisa, the largest city and capital of Somaliland, and Galkayo, the capital of the semi-autonomous region of Puntland. Somalia declared that the agreement between Ethiopia and Somaliland is 'unlawful' and constitutes a threat to its sovereignty. Ethiopia defended the agreement, saying it 'will not affect any party or country.' Ethiopia lost its ports on the Red Sea in the early 1990s, after the Eritrean independence war, which lasted from 1961 to 1991. Somaliland, which has not been recognized as a state since its declaration of independence from Somalia in 1991, operates as a separate administrative, political, and security entity, with the central government unable to exert control over the region. Turkey has launched a mediation initiative between Somalia and Ethiopia, and Turkish Foreign Minister Hakan Fidan has held a meeting with his Ethiopian and Somali counterparts in Ankara in July. Fidan said that 'the tensions between Somalia and Ethiopia will end when Ethiopia reaches the seas through Somalia, as long as Ethiopia's recognition of Somalia's territorial integrity and sovereignty is guaranteed.' Turkey has strong relations with both countries and has become a close ally of Somalia, providing schools, hospitals, and infrastructure, and offering scholarships to Somalis to study in Turkish universities. In 2017, Turkey opened its largest military base outside the country in Mogadishu, and in February this year, it signed a defense and economic cooperation agreement with Somalia, which includes the deployment of Turkish naval forces to protect Somalia's coastline, after the two countries agreed on Turkey's operations to explore oil and gas in three areas off Somalia's coast.
news knowledge.title: تركيا تستضيف جولة ثانية من المفاوضات بين الصومال وإثيوبيا

news knowledge.eng_title: Somali officials in Türkiye for urgent talks with Ethiopia over Somaliland port deal
news knowledge.summary: Somali officials have arrived in Türkiye for urgent talks with Ethiopia over a contentious port access deal with Somaliland. Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has reaffirmed Türkiye's commitment to easing tensions between Ethiopia and Somalia, urging Ethiopia to address Somalia's concerns. The talks, which began in July, aim to resolve the diplomatic dispute between the two East African nations. Somalia's Foreign Minister Ahmed Moallim Fiqi said, 'Our sovereignty is non-negotiable, but we are committed to finding a peaceful resolution.' The dispute centers on Ethiopia's deal with Somaliland, which Somalia regards as an inseparable part of its territory. Turkish Foreign Minister Hakan Fidan has emphasized the importance of 'constructive dialogue' in resolving the issue.
news knowledge.title: Somali officials in Türkiye for urgent talks with Ethiopia over Somaliland port deal
